facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No. 506 of 1957 by the State of Andhra.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 506 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated July 21, 1955 of High Court of Andhra in Writ Appeal No. 122 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 21, 1955, of the High Court of Andhra, Guntur, in Writ Appeal No. 122 of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 8, 1960 by AYYANGAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. December 8. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR., J.-This appeal

facts.text: Respondent joined Madras Police Force as Constable on September 1, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent joined the Madras Police Force as a Constable on September 1, 1939. He became a permanent Head Constable

facts.text: Respondent became permanent Head Constable in 1946.

anchor.surface_text: He became a permanent Head Constable in 1946 and was promoted to officiate as a Sub-Inspector

facts.text: Respondent promoted to officiate as Sub-Inspector on October 1, 1947, probation commenced.

anchor.surface_text: and was promoted to officiate as a Sub-Inspector on October 1, 1947, when his probation companymenced.

facts.text: By order dated September 24, 1950, respondent declared to have completed probation satisfactorily, brought to A list from September 10, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated September 24, 1950, he was declared to have satisfactorily companypleted his period of probation and was brought to the A list

facts.text: On August 3, 1952, District Superintendent of Police, Krishna, issued order reverting respondent to Head Constable from August 14, 1952 for lack of vacancies.

anchor.surface_text: On August 3, 1952, the District Superintendent of Police, Krishna, issued an order reverting the respondent to the rank of Head Constable

facts.text: Reversion extended to large number of officiating Sub-Inspectors promoted from Head Constables.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that such reversion was number companyfined to the respondent alone but extended to a very large number of officiating Sub-Inspectors

facts.text: Inspector-General of Police issued memorandum on January 15, 1953 explaining reversions.

anchor.surface_text: the Inspector-General of Police, Madras, issued a memorandum on January 15, 1953, in the following terms MEMORANDUM.

facts.text: Respondent filed Writ Petition No. 524 of 1953 under Art. 226 in High Court of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Not having obtained any redress by reason of his memorial, the respondent filed before the High Court of Madras a petition under Art. 226

facts.text: Balakrishna Iyer, J. allowed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: Balakrishna Iyer, J., who heard the petition allowed it and issued a direction to the State

facts.text: State appealed, appeal transferred to High Court of Andhra, appeal dismissed on July 21, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The State preferred an appeal from this judgment which was transferred to the High Court of Andhra after that Court. was formed.

facts.text: State obtained certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) and filed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Andhra thereafter moved the High Court for the grant of a certificate and having obtained it, has filed this appeal.

facts.text: Reversion was for administrative reasons, not punishment; contention under Art. 311 abandoned.

anchor.surface_text: the case has proceeded throughout on both sides on the footing that the reversion was effected solely for administrative reasons

facts.text: Respondent later promoted to substantive post of Sub-Inspector.

anchor.surface_text: Now, it is admitted by the Government that the percentage of promotees, was only 24.5 at the time

facts.text: Large number of direct recruits as Sub-Inspectors during police action in Hyderabad with assurance no reversion.

facts.text: Temporary posts abolished after police action, necessitating absorption of direct recruits.

anchor.surface_text: a number of temporary posts created for special purposes during the disturbed period immediately following the police action in Hyderabad had to be abolished

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment, dismissed writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly allowed, the judgment of the High Court set aside and Writ Petition No. 524 of 1953 dismissed.

on a certificate under Art. 133 1   c  of the Constitution. The respondent joined the Madras Police Force as a Constable on September 1, 1939. He became a permanent Head Constable in 1946 and was promoted to officiate as a Sub-Inspector on October 1, 1947, when his probation companymenced.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent filed before the High Court of Madras a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution  Writ Petition No. 524 of 1953  and prayed therein that the State of Madras may be directed by the issue of a writ of mandamus to refrain from enforcing the order reverting him as Head Constable but to companysider his claim to be companyfirmed as Sub-Inspector on the basis of his seniority in the list of approved probationers.

Though in his petition under Art. 226 filed before the High Court of Madras, the petitioner had alleged that his reversion from the officiating post of Sub-Inspector to his substantive post as Head Constable was a reduction in rank within the meaning of Art. 311 2  of the Constitution, i.e., a reduction by way of punishment effected without giving him an opportunity to show cause therefor, this companytention was abandoned early in the proceedings before the Court and the case has proceeded throughout on both sides on the footing that the reversion was effected solely for administrative reasons and number for any misconduct by way of punishment.

Balakrishna Iyer, J., who heard the petition allowed it and issued a direction to the State to forbear from giving effect to the order of reversion if the petitioner by virtue of his seniority among promoters can be included in the 30 per cent. already referred to.

Right of probationers and approved probationers to appointment to vacancies-A 7 vacancy in any class or category shall number be filled by the appointment of a person who has number yet companymenced his probation in such class or category when an approved probationer or a probationer therein is available for such appointment. Rule 5. Order of discharge of probationers and approved probationers- The order in which probationers and approved probationers. shall be discharged for want of vacancies shall be- first, the probationers in order of juniority and ,second, the approved probationers in order of juniority.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 5. Order of discharge of probationers and approved probationers- The order in which probationers and approved probationers. shall be discharged for want of vacancies shall be- first, the probationers in order of juniority and ,second, the approved probationers in order of juniority. The order of discharge laid down in sub- rule a  may be departed from in cases where such order would involve excessive expenditure on traveling allowance or exceptional administrative inconvenience. The other rules merely carry out the principles underlying those extracted and do number need to be set out.

issues.text: Was there a violation of the Service Rules when the respondent was reverted as Head Constable?

anchor.surface_text: 1  Was there a violation of the Service Rules when the respondent was reverted as Head Constable?

issues.text: If there was such a violation, do breaches of Service Rules by themselves constitute an infringement of the legal rights of officers to whom they apply, entitling them to seek remedies therefor before Courts.

anchor.surface_text: 2  If there was such a violation, do breaches of Service Rules by themselves constitute an infringement of the legal rights of officers to whom they apply, entitling them to seek remedies therefor before Courts.

issues.text: whether there had been an infraction of r. 3 of the Service Rules by reason of the proportion of rank-promotees being less than 30 per cent. of the total number of Sub-Inspectors in service at the date of the respondents reversion

anchor.surface_text: The first point to be dealt with is as to whether there had been an infraction of r. 3 of the Service Rules by reason of the proportion of rank-promotees being less than 30 per cent. of the total number of Sub- Inspectors in service at the date of the respondents reversion.

issues.text: whether r. 4 of the Service Rules by which confirmations were regulated, had been violated in promoting the more junior direct recruits to substantive posts in preference to rankpromotees like the respondent who were senior to them

anchor.surface_text: The next question is as to whether r. 4 of the Service Rules by which confirmations were regulated, had been violated in promoting the more junior direct recruits to substantive posts in preference to rankpromotees like the respondent who were senior to them in service in the sense that the latters probation as officiating Sub-Inspectors commenced earlier.

issues.text: whether rank-promotees and officers directly recruited form or do not form the same class or category becoming integrated into one Service on their initial appointment to the Service

anchor.surface_text: depends largely on whether rank- promotees and officers directly recruited form or do number form the same class or category becoming integrated into, one Service on their initial appointment to the Service.

issues.text: whether the reversion infringed r. 5(a) or could be justified under r. 5(b) as exceptional administrative inconvenience

anchor.surface_text: it cannot be contended that the reversion of the respondent infringed r. 5 a . But this apart, the impugned order could also be sustained on the basis of the provision contained in cl. b of r. 5 which reads The order of discharge laid down in sub-rule a may be departed from in cases where such order would involve excessive expenditure on travelling allowance or exceptional administrative inconvenience.

anchor.surface_text: the petitioner had alleged that his reversion from the officiating post of Sub-Inspector to his substantive post as Head Constable was a reduction in rank within the meaning of Art. 311 2  of the Constitution, i.e., a reduction by way of punishment effected without giving him an opportunity to show cause therefor,

In other words, the 30 per cent. was the ceiling fixed and not any minimum and the rule in effect guaranteed direct recruits a minimum proportion of 70 per cent. There was therefore no violation of this rule when the proportion of rank-promotees fell to a little below 25 per cent. at the relevant date.

anchor.surface_text: Article 311 2 being out of the way. the questions that arise fall under two heads 1 Was there a violation of the Service Rules... 2 If there was such a violation, do breaches of Service Rules by themselves constitute an infringement of the legal rights... In the view that we have taken that there has been no breach of the Service Rules... the question as to whether an infraction of a Service Rule confers a legal right... does not arise.

arguments.claim: No legal obligation to retain approved probationers in officiating posts despite assurances to directs

anchor.surface_text: Before leaving r. 5... the observation of the High Court... seems to imply that if the Government found itself in difficulty owing to the assurances given to the officers directly recruited, they could under the rules have solved it, not by ordering the reversion of the rank-promotees but by continuing them in their officiating posts... Of course, as a measure of relief... but it is quite a different thing to import a legal and enforceable obligation

holdings.text: The words 'up to, not more than 30 per cent' in Rule 3 fix the maximum percentage (ceiling) of rank-promotees, not a minimum; no violation when proportion below 30%.

anchor.surface_text: We consider that this construction is erroneous, particularly in the context of the provision as regards direct recruits, in regard to whom there is no limitation placed on the proportion which they could have in the Service. Taken in conjunction with this provision it is clear that the words up to, not more than merely fix the maximum percentage of rank-promotees in the category, leaving it to the appointing authorities to adopt any percentage below this figure. We consequently endorse the view which the learned Judges of the Andhra High Court took in dissenting from the construction which the learned Single Judge placed on the scope of r. 3. The reversion of the respondent cannot, therefore, be challenged on the ground that there had been an infraction of r. 3 of the Service Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'up to, not more than' as ceiling confirmed by absence of limit on direct recruits; endorses High Court dissent against single judge.

holdings.text: Rule 4 not violated: rank-promotees and direct recruits form separate categories until absorption as full members; confirmations and seniority operate within each category.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is as to whether r. 4 of the Service Rules by which confirmations were regulated, had been violated in promoting the more junior direct recruits to substantive posts in preference to rankpromotees like the respondent who were senior to them in service in the sense that the latters probation as officiating Sub-Inspectors commenced earlier. ... We, therefore, consider that there was no violation of the rule as to seniority prescribed by r. 4 in the appointment of the direct recruits to substantive posts before the absorption of rank promotees like the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate categories pre-absorption; r3 proportions apply at substantive stage; rejects unified seniority argument; integration only post-absorption.

holdings.text: No infringement of Rule 5(a): juniority for reversion determined separately within each category (promotees vs direct recruits).

anchor.surface_text: it cannot be contended that the reversion of the respondent infringed r. 5 a . But this apart, the impugned order could also be sustained on the basis of the provision contained in cl. b of r. 5 which reads The order of discharge laid down in sub-rule a may be departed from in cases where such order would involve excessive expenditure on traveling allowance or exceptional administrative inconvenience.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from separate categories under r4 and r3; reverses confirmation priority for reversion purposes.

holdings.text: Reversion justified under Rule 5(b) proviso: departure from r5(a) permitted due to exceptional administrative inconvenience from Hyderabad police action, assurances to direct recruits, and abolition of temporary posts.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the Government explained their reason for the order for reversion of rank-promotees in the affidavit... This reversion of rank-promoted Sub-Inspectors was rendered absolutely necessary in the exigencies of service and for administrative purposes... it appears to us that the order of reversion passed would be justified as being covered by the last words of cl. b even if the order laid down in r. 5 a were infringed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts of Hyderabad situation (direct recruits assurances, temporary posts abolished, Sub-Inspectors returning) constitute exceptional inconvenience; facts accepted unchallenged.

holdings.text: No legal or enforceable obligation under rules to retain approved probationers (rank-promotees) in officiating posts pending absorption instead of reverting them.

anchor.surface_text: Before leaving r. 5... the observation of the High Court... seems to imply that if the Government found itself in difficulty owing to the assurances given to the officers directly recruited, they could under the rules have solved it, not by ordering the reversion of the rank-promotees but by continuing them in their officiating posts... Of course, as a measure of relief... but it is quite a different thing to import a legal and enforceable obligation

holdings.reasoning_summary: r5(a) expressly permits reversion of approved probationers; policy relief optional, not mandatory right.

holdings.text: No breach of Service Rules; question of whether breach confers enforceable legal right entitling court remedy does not arise.

anchor.surface_text: In the view that we have taken that there has been no breach of the Service Rules in ordering the reversion of the respondent as a Head Constable, the question as to whether an infraction of a Service Rule confers a legal right which could be agitated in Court does not arise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Moot as no breach found; unnecessary to decide.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly allowed, the judgment of the High Court set aside and Writ Petition No. 524 of 1953 dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; judgment and order of the High Court set aside; Writ Petition No. 524 of 1953 dismissed.

edges.explanation: Argument refers to approved probationers warranting retention until 'substantive vacancies', aligning with and supporting their characterization as fit for confirmation when vacancies arise.

Argument discusses 'rank-promotee approved probationers' and inability to 'revert directs', directly pertaining to the classification of rank-promotees versus directly recruited officers as the same or different class/category.
Definition of approved probationer as fit for confirmation on vacancies arising grounds the argument's discussion of retaining such rank-promotee probationers until substantive vacancies.
CONST_ART226 concept within the same cluster addresses the core issue of the petition

edges.explanation: CONST_ART226 mention immediately precedes the issue (6045 to 6065 gap), indicating the writ jurisdiction under Art. 226 addresses the question of reduction in rank
h1's finding of no Rule 3 violation supports h6's overall holding of no breach of Service Rules.
h1 finds no violation of Rule 3 (proportion below 30%), addressing the claim of Service Rules violation in i1.

anchor.surface_text: We consider that this construction is erroneous, particularly in the context of the provision as regards direct recruits, in regard to whom there is no limitation placed on the proportion which they could have in the Service. Taken in conjunction with this provision it is clear that the words up to, not more than merely fix the maximum percentage of rank-promotees in the category, leaving it to the appointing authorities to adopt any percentage below this figure. We consequently endorse the view which the learned Judges of the Andhra High Court took in dissenting from the construction which the learned Single Judge placed on the scope of r. 3. The reversion of the respondent cannot, therefore, be challenged on the ground that there had been an infraction of r. 3 of the Service Rules.
The appeal is accordingly allowed, the judgment of the High Court set aside and Writ Petition No. 524 of 1953 dismissed.

edges.explanation: h2's finding on Rule 4 supports h6's no breach holding.
h2 finds Rule 4 not violated (separate categories), addressing Service Rules violation in i1.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is as to whether r. 4 of the Service Rules by which confirmations were regulated, had been violated in promoting the more junior direct recruits to substantive posts in preference to rankpromotees like the respondent who were senior to them in service in the sense that the latters probation as officiating Sub-Inspectors commenced earlier. ... We, therefore, consider that there was no violation of the rule as to seniority prescribed by r. 4 in the appointment of the direct recruits to substantive posts before the absorption of rank promotees like the respondent.
The appeal is accordingly allowed, the judgment of the High Court set aside and Writ Petition No. 524 of 1953 dismissed.

edges.explanation: h3 supports h6 by confirming no Rule 5(a) infringement.
h3 finds no infringement of Rule 5(a), addressing i1.

anchor.surface_text: it cannot be contended that the reversion of the respondent infringed r. 5 a . But this apart, the impugned order could also be sustained on the basis of the provision contained in cl. b of r. 5 which reads The order of discharge laid down in sub-rule a may be departed from in cases where such order would involve excessive expenditure on traveling allowance or exceptional administrative inconvenience.
The appeal is accordingly allowed, the judgment of the High Court set aside and Writ Petition No. 524 of 1953 dismissed.

The appeal is accordingly allowed, the judgment of the High Court set aside and Writ Petition No. 524 of 1953 dismissed.
